data.text:
Joseph Hellerâs 1961 war comedy Catch-22 is one of the most beloved novels of the 20th century, not to mention one of the funniest. Here are a few interesting bits of information about both how Hellerâs story came to be and the legacy that it left behind.

1. Joseph Heller sketched out Catch-22âs concept and characters in about 90 minutes.

Heller recalled the birth of his most famous novel as if it were a classic movie scene. While lying in bed in his apartment on the West Side of Manhattan in the early 1950s, Heller was struck with what would become the iconic opening line of the story: âIt was love at first sight. The first time he saw the chaplain, âSomeoneâ fell madly in love with him,â with âheâ and âsomeoneâ holding the place for Hellerâs protagonistâs eventual name, Yossarian. Over the course of an hour and a half, he developed the basic plot and collection of characters that heâd ultimately pour into his novel.

2. Joseph Heller wrote the first chapter of Catch-22 at work the following day.

Heller was an advertising copywriter when he had the idea for the novel. He spent the workday following his creative epiphany, writing out the entire first chapter of what would become Catch-22 by hand. He submitted the chapter to New World Writing magazine by way of a literary agent, and a full year passed before he completed a second chapter.

3. Joseph Heller went through four numbers for the bookâs title before landing on 22.

The original title of the story, as published in New World Writing, was Catch-18. Acquiescing to his publisherâs qualms about confusion with the WWII novel Mila 18, Heller dragged his title through a sequence of changes: Catch-11 (which was deemed too similar to the contemporary film Oceanâs 11), possibly followed by Catch-17 (which posed the same problem with Billy Wilderâs war movie Stalag 17), and then Catch-14 (which Hellerâs editor thought just didnât sound funny enough). Finally, everyone landed on Catch-22.

4.Many of Catch-22âs characters were based on Joseph Hellerâs friends.

Heller was a veteran of World War II, and he based a number of Catch-22âs characters on his army buddies. Yossarianâs name came from fellow WWII veteran Francis Yohannan. Additionally, the sociopathic Milo Minderbinder was designed with Hellerâs childhood friend, Marvin âBeansyâ Winkler of Coney Island, in mind.

5. Joseph Heller was frequently asked about Yossarianâs ethnicity and religion.

The protagonistâs ethnic background has been cause for debate since the bookâs publication. In Catch-22, Heller introduces Yossarian as Assyrian, despite the fact that his surname suggests otherwise. In response to readersâ curiosity, Heller amended Yossarianâs heritage in Catch-22âs 1994 sequel Closing Time. In the second book, Yossarian was declared Armenian.

However, the most common question Heller received regarding Yossarianâs background concerned his religion, as many readers sought confirmation that the character shared Hellerâs Jewish faith. In 1972, Heller responded to these quandaries in a letter to Northeastern University professor James Nagel, stating, âYossarian isnât Jewish and was not intended to be. On the other hand, no effort was expended to make him anything else.â

6. Earlier drafts of Catch-22 included a greater Jewish influence.

As Nagel writes in a section of Biographies of Books: The Compositional Histories of Notable American Writings devoted to Catch-22, âThe early drafts of the novel, particularly the sketches and notecards, have a somewhat more âJewishâ emphasis than does the published novel. In Judaism, âeighteenâ [the original titular numeric] is a significant number in that the eighteenth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, âchai,â means âlivingâ or âlife.â â¦ Thematically, the title âCatch-18â would thus contain a subtle reference to the injunction in the Torah to choose life, a principle endorsed by Yossarian at the end of the novel when he deserts.â

7. Catch-22 was initially only popular on the East Coast.

While Catch-22 stands today as a universally appreciated political satire, it proved unsurprisingly polarizing in the heated climate of the 1960s. High school and college students, particularly those who lived on the East Coast, were early fans of the novel. As Heller told George Plimpton of The Paris Review in 1974, by 1962 sales were dwindling: âCatch-22 was not making much money. It was selling steadily (eight hundred to two thousand copies a week)âmostly by word of mouthâbut it had never come close to the New York Times best-seller list.â

8. Catch-22 earned the wrath of the East Coastâs premier critics.

Catch-22 wasnât universally panned, but it certainly didnât win any popularity contests among the upper echelon of the literary criticism circuit. The original 1961 New York Times review opens: âCatch-22, by Joseph Heller, is not an entirely successful novel. It is not even a good novel. It is not even a good novel by conventional standards.â (The reviewer did like its comedy and originality, though.)

A second review from TheÂ New York Times called the book ârepetitive and monotonous,â as well as, curiously, âtoo shortâ to properly flesh out its character ensemble. Similarly, TheÂ New Yorker accused Hellerâs prose of âgiv[ing] the impression of having been shouted onto paper,â adding, âwhat remains is a debris of sour jokes.â

9. Joseph Heller was principally inspired by one novel.

While Heller recognized a number of influences on his writing, including novelists Louis-Ferdinand CÃ©line, Evelyn Waugh, and Vladimir Nabakov, the author once identified a single work that convinced him to write Catch-22: the dark World War I comedy The Good Soldier Å vejk by Czech author Jaroslav HaÅ¡ek.

10. Joseph Heller was accused of plagiarism.

Thirty-seven years after the publication of Catch-22, the book came under fire for similarities to the 1950 war novel Face of a Hero. Londoner Lewis Pollock made the connection in 1998 and contacted The Sunday Times to condemn Catch-22 as a rip-off of the obscure Louis Falstein story.

From there, the accusation gained international traction and eventually reached Heller himself. The author rejected Pollockâs claims, insisting that he had never read Face of a Hero prior to the controversy. Furthermore, his editor combated the theory by asking his interrogators why Falstein, who had only passed away in 1995, would never have broadcast any such concerns if they had borne any weight.

Also defending Heller this time around? The New York Times. Mel Gussow wrote in the paper, âAn examination of the two books leads this reader to conclude that the similarities between the two can easily be attributed to the shared wartime experiences of the authors.â

11. A deleted Catch-22 chapter gave Major Major a different backstory.

One of Hellerâs more absurd characters is Major Major Major Major, cursed with his unfortunate handle and unfavorable likeness to Henry Fonda. Originally, Heller planned to delve into Majorâs past in the States. He had written Major Major as a former English teacher from Vermont with a distaste for Henry James.

12. One Catch-22 character provided the namesake of a Marvel Comics institution.

The Marvel Comics superhero Isaiah Bradley undergoes a series of experiments during World War II to turn him into a âBlack Captain Americaâ at the military base Camp Cathcart, named for Catch-22âs rank-climbing soldier, Col. Chuck Cathcart.

13. Catch-22âs original manuscript lives at Brandeis University.

After the novel was published in 1961, Heller donated his original manuscript to Brandeis University. The Massachusetts school preserves the document today, and honored the collected works of its author in 2009 on the 10-year anniversary of his death.

14. CBS tried to adapt Catch-22 into a sitcom.

While director Mike Nicholsâ 1970 feature film adaptation of Catch-22 didnât find huge critical or commercial success, it was hardly as big a failure as the small screen endeavor inspired by Hellerâs book. In 1973, ABC produced and broadcast a Catch-22 sitcom pilot starring Richard Dreyfuss as Yossarian. The series never got a second episode. Hulu had greater success, turning the book into a miniseries in 2019.

15. An NBC host committed-Catch-22-inspired vandalism.

Journalist John Chancellor, known best as a host and correspondent on NBC Nightly News for 23 years, played host of NBCâs Today show between 1961 and â62. During his tenure on the daytime program, Chancellorâa fan of Hellerâs newly published novelâhad personalized stickers reading âYossarian Livesâ printed, and pioneered a practical joke of placing them (discreetly) all over the hallways, offices, and bathrooms of NBCâs headquarters. He revealed his secret to Heller over a round of drinks following the authorâs guest appearance on Today.
